text: Tonight, around 9:20 PM ET, I’ll be joining @Maddow to discuss the brazen attempt from some Georgia lawmakers to suppress voters. I’ve made it very clear we are not going to back down. Be sure to tune in!

It’s been a tough couple of weeks for Georgians & my heart goes out to those impacted by the storms this morning in Newnan—as well as to our neighbors in Alabama who also experienced devastation. My staff & I are available to assist families recovering in whatever way possible.

When I’m home in Georgia, folks don’t want to talk about Senate procedures like the filibuster. They want to talk about voting rights, health care, education & more.
 
It’s time the Senate stops safeguarding procedural relics that reek of Jim Crow & starts working for the people.

Georgia’s sweeping “election reform” bill isn’t about reforming elections—it’s about further suppressing the vote & taking away the people's voice. This is democracy in reverse. Congress must act swiftly to secure voting rights & every option must be on the table to do so.

It’s been just over a week since the horrific tragedy in Atlanta that took eight lives too soon. As we mourn, we also must commit to standing up against anti-Asian rhetoric & actions—which have risen rampantly throughout the pandemic—& work toward an active peace. #StopAsianHate
Decades later, Dr. King’s work is still unfinished. We must build upon his legacy & fiercely protect our access to the ballot box. #TheVoteIsSacred http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExbGSPWXMAY4y-g.jpg

Yesterday, on the anniversary of Dr. King & activists arriving in Montgomery, my church member @Cannonfor58 was arrested for seeking transparency in gov’t. It’s abhorrent.
 
This democracy belongs to the people. We’re exhausted—we’ve been exhausted—but we’re still fighting.

Join me live as I discuss the events that unfolded last night—in what is a blatant attack on our democracy & rights as Georgians.

I made a promise when I came to the Senate to never stop fighting for the sacred right to vote—no matter what. https://twitter.com/i/broadcasts/1OdKrVZMbOwKX

RT @newsdamian .@SenAlexPadilla, pictured here feeding farm workers in Gilroy, CA on #CesarChavezDay 2018, co-sponsors legislation to protect farm workers from the heat. 
The “legislation Will Help Protect Safety and Health of Workers Exposed to Dangerous Heat Conditions in the Workplace” http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Exb68QiUUAEly5D.jpg

Our bill is named after Asunción Valdivia, a CA farmworker who died in 2004 after picking grapes for ten hours straight in 105-degree heat.
 
Mr. Valdivia's death was completely preventable — in his honor and for all of our workers on the front lines today, we must act.

Between extreme heat from wildfires & the COVID pandemic, workers in CA and across the U.S. have risked their health & safety to keep our country running.
 
I'm teaming up with @SenSherrodBrown & @SenCortezMasto to hold employers accountable and protect workers from heat stress.

I thank Chairwoman @NydiaVelazquez, Ranking Member @RepBlaine, @RepYoungKim, Chairman @SenatorCardin, @SenatorCollins, @SenatorShaheen, and all those who voted to support small businesses in both the House and the Senate by passing this bill.

When I ran for office, I promised to work with people of good faith on both sides of the aisle to get things done for Georgians. The bipartisan passage of the PPP Extension Act reflects that commitment.

This legislation will extend that deadline, allowing more of our small businesses the opportunity to access critically-needed funds. It also creates a one month processing period to avoid bureaucratic delays in distribution of funds.

This bill originated with local business owners in my District, who came to me with their concerns regarding the PPP application period being set to end in March and how it would impact small businesses.

I applaud the Senate for their quick and decisive action in passing my bipartisan #PPPExtensionAct yesterday. Small businesses are hurting. It’s not a Democratic problem or a Republican problem, it’s an American problem.

If you have any questions on these programs, or other available COVID relief options, please contact my office at (516) 739-3008 or (202) 225-5516. We are here to help.
For the Shuttered Venue Operators Grant (SVOG) program and the Restaurant Revitalization Fund (RRF) program, prospective applicants will need to pre-register here: https://sam.gov/SAM/.

The $28.6 billion Restaurant Revitalization Fund (RRF) is expected to launch in early April.
 
RRF will provide grants to restaurants equal to their pandemic revenue loss, up to $10 million per entity, or $5 million per physical location.

More information will be announced soon.

The Shuttered Venue Operators Grant (SVOG) program authorizes $16 billion in grants for live entertainment venues. Eligible applicants may qualify for grants equal to 45% of their gross earned revenue.

SVOG is set to launch on April 8. Sign-up for updates:https://www.svograntportal.sba.gov/s/

What a thrilling, moving visit by my friend @VP Harris - her energy & passion inspiring us to rebuild a child care industry devastated by the pandemic. Child care workers are heroes.

The American Rescue Plan made one of the greatest investments in reducing child poverty in history. In a country that has as many resources as ours, no kid should have to go to bed hungry, grow up without an adequate education, or suffer without medication when they’re sick.

Over the last year, I’ve visited day cares across CT & I’ve seen how hard caregivers work, how joyful kids are to be with each other & what a relief it is for working parents to know their children are somewhere safe and happy.

The American Rescue Plan made major investments in day care centers like New Haven’s Boys & Girls Club - affordable child care is absolutely fundamental to getting our economy back on track & giving working parents the helping hand they’ve been missing.

For decades, DOD & Admins of both parties have agreed the draft is unnecessary & obsolete. No young person, regardless of gender, should be subject to or forced to register for a draft. That’s why I’m reintroducing my legislation to abolish the military draft.

Every year millions of young Americans are subjected to an unjust policy that violates their civil liberties for so-called “military preparedness.” Those who fail to register can face lifelong, severe penalties, which disproportionately affect low-income Americans.

This debate misses the point. The stories go on & highlight why the ACA has been such a consequential step forward for so many Granite Staters & Americans. But our work isn't over – I'll continue to fight to expand access to quality, affordable health care that all Americans deserve.

As a college student, Tiffany from Dover struggled to afford the costs of treatment & care for her autoimmune disorder. Though she had health insurance, it was the norm for companies to deny care or increase costs for Americans w/pre-existing conditions. The ACA changed that.

James from Keene & his wife lost their health insurance after she was laid off – making a stressful situation even worse. The ACA helps Americans when they need a hand because cost should never be a barrier to care, & allowed this couple to #GetCovered thru the ACA Marketplace.

Christine from Goffstown had left her job and with it, her employer-sponsored health care plan. To make matters worse, the high cost of COBRA made paying to stay on her old plan out of the question. The ACA opened up options that she wouldn’t have been able to afford otherwise.

David from Merrimack is a proud dad who wants the best for his kids. When his son graduated from college amid an economic downturn, David was worried he'd be left without health insurance. Thanks to the ACA, Americans under 26 like David’s son can stay on their parents’ plan.

This week, we celebrated the 11th anniversary of the ACA, legislation that changed the way we view health care in the U.S. – as a right, not a privilege. To mark the occasion, I want to share some of the stories I've heard from Granite Staters on what the ACA means for them.
